content: > It wasn't clear how the draw had to be outputted, so I made a quick change.

I changed the clash type from Reverse to Fastest so the description would be visible, I apologize to everyone for the bad experience. It was my first clash and I promise that the next ones will be much more thoughtful. Greetings!

I got this as a reverse clash once, and it passed 100% with all testcases (using the assumption that it's a classic "who wins a fight with hp and attack") but only 60% in the validators, because now that I see the actual solution, it's not even close to what I thought.
Maybe if the output was something like "Dwarf 180", it would've been easy to guess, but there's no other output, so I really don't think this is a good reverse clash.

This should have never been approved for reverse mode. It's impossible to know the right algorithm in reverse mode, and you can EASILY do something that passes all the visible tests and fail most of the validators. I assumed it's comparing hitpoints divided by opponent_attack and passed all tests, got 40% from validators.

Absolute garbage.

This is not currently a good reverse clash. The tests and validators are quite different and lead to issues.

I just got this in a Reverse clash and got 100% on test cases with the below Ruby code:

n = gets.chomp
h = gets.to_i
a = gets.to_i
N=second_name = gets.chomp
H=second_health = gets.to_i
A=second_attack = gets.to_i
while [h,H].min > 0
  h -= A
  H -= a
end
puts h < 0 && H < 0 ? "Draw" : h < 0 ? N : n

----
Basically, I was seeing who would actually win in a fight between the two players assuming that each attacks simultaneously in turns until one or both of them died. This is a common solution for other clashes like this and when I got 100% on the test cases I assumed I had solved it, but then I got 60% on your validators. A Reverse clash needs to be clearly reverse-engineerable from the tests without ambiguity, otherwise it's impossible to know whether your code is correct or not...

I think this needs to be corrected ASAP. I suggest swapping "Greenskins vs Legions of the Damned" with "Monsters vs Legions of the Damned", and then also adding a new test/validator pair that your code would consider a draw that wouldn't be under my code:
e.g.
Name_1
1
10
Name_2
11
0
Output:
Draw

(My code would output Name_1, since Name_1 would win in a fight, but your code considers this a draw... which is quite inaccurate, imo, but if that's the way you want it then you need better tests to show it)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice and quick

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I really like gamified clashes such as this one... so I am already biased (maybe).

Fun and good practice for beginners and intermediate programmers.

Good job, @Putra.

Cases
* This is a Reverse-mode-only clash, but there is only one invisible validator which requires the output of {{Draw}}. The players won't know that this is required based on the visible tests alone. Please have at least one visible test to require the output of {{Draw}}.

Thanks.
I improved it. Thank your for your comment!
Thank you! Good point. I added it to goal description.
Very interesting comment, I did not notice this with my solution. I admit that I am a bit sorry I didn't see this when checking this clash out.
Sorry for that, next time I will add more test cases and better validators. I'm not very experienced in creating contributions, can I still change it?
Sorry for that, next time I will add more test cases and better validators. I'm not very experienced in creating contributions, can I still change it?

I cannot see any changelog, did you add this "or Draw"? Thank you!
It was my first contribution and I am not happy about it. Next ones are much better.
I don't think so ):

You can always change a contribution after approval, but it's preferred that the changes are made only to fix issues rather than for other reasons. I think it's justifiable in the current case.

Please also mention what you've changed in a standalone comment so that others coming to the contribution view will know.
Yes, see my comment to your other comment above.
Now it's the opposite issue. You need to have the same coverage in the visible tests and the invisible validators.
Ok, I get it now. I changed it and added one more test. Thank you.
